albase:priest-allowcharselonce-desc:
The priest can grant you the right to change your class once — but not for free.

He demands a cleansing rite: track down and destroy those who defile the surroundings.

After the rite you will receive a blessing and can use .charsel once. You can only do this again after 90 in-game days.
albase:priest-allowcharselonce-reward: Priest: The blessing is granted. You can now use .charsel once. Next time — in 90 in-game days.
albase:priest-allowcharselonce-journal-t:
The priest in the temple offered a rare mercy: the right to change your class once.

But a blessing is never free.

He demands a cleansing rite:
Track down and destroy those who defile the surroundings.

The targets of the rite can vary; the priest will name new foes when you accept the task.

Complete the rite and return to receive the blessing.
albase:priest-allowcharselonce-reward-jo:
The rite is complete.

The priest granted the blessing and allowed a single change of class and appearance.

Use the .charsel command when you are ready.
This can be done only once.

You will not be able to receive this permission again for at least 90 in-game days.
albase:dialogue-priest-intro: Peace be with you. What do you seek here?
albase:dialogue-priest-changeclass: I want to change my class.
albase:dialogue-priest-aboutblessing: Tell me about the rite and the blessing.
albase:dialogue-priest-close-answer: Go in peace. When you are ready, return.
albase:no-quest-available-priest: The rite to change your class can be performed only once every 90 days.
albase:no-quest-available-priest-cooldow: The rite to change your class will be available in {0} day(s).
albase:dialogue-priest-whoareyou-answer: I have served here for many years. I do not seek power—only to keep people from despair and to remind them that order is still possible.
albase:dialogue-priest-abouttemple-answe: You stand in the Church of the White Lotus, in the parish people call “Crossroads”. Here roads and fates meet: travelers find shelter, and the lost find a chance to begin again.
albase:dialogue-priest-aboutblessing-ans: A blessing is not a coin. It has a cost: patience and deeds. The cleansing rite is simple—find those who defile the surroundings, and prove you can finish what you start.
albase:dialogue-priest-final-text: The blessing is granted. You may now change class and appearance once via .charsel. You can only receive this again after 90 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-firstimpression-desc:
The innkeeper dislikes noise and does not trust words. He judges people by what they do.

Do a short job nearby and he'll hand you supplies without extra talk.

This job is available only once.
albase:innkeeper-firstimpression-journal:
The innkeeper spoke in short, sharp sentences.

He said he does not give work to everyone—he tests first.

The job is simple: travel a bit on foot and deal with the target he assigns.

No noise. Then return.
albase:innkeeper-firstimpression-reward: Innkeeper: You'll do. More work will come—no more often than once every 40 days.
albase:innkeeper-quietpatrol-desc:
At night there is always something rustling around the inn. The innkeeper hates trouble at his doorstep.

Walk the area, put down what comes too close, and don't put on a performance.

He pays in supplies.

The innkeeper's work rotates every 40 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-quietpatrol-journal-tex:
The innkeeper told you to make a round.

At night there is always something rustling around the inn. He wants it quiet at his doorstep.

Go on foot, clear what he points at, then return.
albase:innkeeper-quietpatrol-reward: Innkeeper: Good enough. Keep my doorstep quiet.
albase:innkeeper-badcustomers-desc:
Some people come to an inn not for food, but for noise. The innkeeper cannot stand drunk, loud braggarts.

Deal with what prowls nearby, and get some distance under your feet.

He'll pay with something useful for the road.

The innkeeper's work rotates every 40 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-badcustomers-journal-te:
The innkeeper said: “Bad customers get sent away quietly.”

Something is prowling near the inn and scaring people. Deal with it without dragging trouble to the door.

Then return.
albase:innkeeper-badcustomers-reward: Innkeeper: Next time use your head, not your fists. But it'll do.
albase:innkeeper-silentdeliveries-desc:
The innkeeper tests your reaction, not your strength. Sometimes he provokes on purpose—just to see if you'll snap.

Go farther than usual. Clear what blocks the road. Return without stories.

He pays in supplies for the road.

The innkeeper's work rotates every 40 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-silentdeliveries-journa:
He gave you an errand and watched as if expecting you to argue.

This is not about strength—it's about keeping your head: go farther than usual on foot, clear the problem, and return without stories.
albase:innkeeper-silentdeliveries-reward: Innkeeper: I don't smile, but I got it. You came back breathing.
albase:innkeeper-foxthief-desc:
Something stole supplies from the inn. Small tracks, red fur, and pure audacity.

The innkeeper wants it to end quietly—no laughing patrons and no empty shelves.

Fix it and you'll get your share.

The innkeeper's work rotates every 40 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-foxthief-journal-text:
In the morning the innkeeper noticed something missing.

“A fox. Red. Bold.
Stole something edible and ran into the brush.”

Find the fox and end the problem. Then return.
albase:innkeeper-cellarwatch-desc:
The innkeeper keeps things in his cellar that should stay undisturbed. But at night you can sometimes hear scraping and shuffling.

He won't explain what's stored there—he just wants the job done.

Keep it quiet and he'll pay in supplies.

The innkeeper's work rotates every 40 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-cellarwatch-journal-tex:
The innkeeper said: “If you hear creaking at night—it's not the wind.”

Check around and push back whatever is drawn to the cellar and supplies. Quietly. Then return.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-firstimpressio:
You'll do.

Take some food and a couple bandages.

If you want more work—come back later.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-quietpatrol-fi:
It's quiet at my door—and I like that.

Take the supplies. No stories.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-badcustomers-f:
No noise—good.

The bag and twine will help. The rest is a bonus.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-silentdeliveri:
You came back. Means your head is still attached.

Bread and supplies. Remember: people here like silence.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-foxthief-final:
There.

The fox is fed—you will be too.

Take it. And don't tell the whole town.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-cellarwatch-fi:
The cellar should be quiet.

Tonight it is.

Bandages and supplies. Take them.
albase:innkeeper-firstimpression-reward-:
The test is done.

The innkeeper decided you can handle quiet work.

If you want more, his jobs rotate about once every 40 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-quietpatrol-reward-jour:
The area around the inn is quieter.

The innkeeper prefers it that way.

He paid you without extra words.
albase:innkeeper-badcustomers-reward-jou:
Fewer bad guests linger near the inn.

The innkeeper noted you didn't put on a show.

To him, that matters more than brute force.
albase:innkeeper-silentdeliveries-reward:
The errand is done.

He didn't ask for details—only results.

Everything else is talk.
albase:innkeeper-foxthief-reward-journal:
The fox thief won't steal from the inn again.

The innkeeper said, “Better this way.”

And, as usual, pretended he didn't care.
albase:innkeeper-cellarwatch-reward-jour:
The night is quieter.

The innkeeper still won't say what he guards down there, but the cellar can “sleep” again.

He paid you right away.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-whoareyou-answ:
I run the inn. I see a lot of people.

I don't like the noisy ones. Drunks—least of all.

If you came to chatter, wrong door.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-aboutplace-ans:
An inn. Roof, food, fire. And silence—if we're lucky.

If you can behave, you're welcome.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-whyso-answer:
Smiles are for people who don't owe anything.

I don't know you yet.

Don't push it—it's easier that way.
albase:no-quest-available-innkeeper: Innkeeper: No work right now. Good.
albase:innkeeper-missingmugs-desc:
In the morning, some mugs are missing from the inn. No one confesses, but the rumors are spreading.

The innkeeper wants you to handle it quietly.

The innkeeper's work rotates every 40 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-missingmugs-journal-tex:
The innkeeper said, “Mugs don't walk away on their own.”

Something is prowling around the inn at night. Deal with it—and make sure everything is in its place by morning.
albase:innkeeper-talkingbarrel-desc:
Something in the cellar is knocking and scraping, as if a barrel decided to talk. Patrons are already placing bets.

The innkeeper wants silence—and no stories.

The innkeeper's work rotates every 40 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-talkingbarrel-journal-t:
At night, you can hear it from the cellar: knocking, scraping, and what sounds like footsteps.

The innkeeper said, “This is not a joke. Make it stop.”
albase:innkeeper-doorposter-desc:
Someone is leaving notes on the inn's door that make the innkeeper's eye twitch.

He won't read them aloud—he just wants it to stop.

The innkeeper's work rotates every 40 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-doorposter-journal-text:
Another note on the door.

The innkeeper said, “One more time, and I'll go out there myself.”

Make sure they stop writing.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-missingmugs-fi:
The mugs are in place—means the night was quiet.

Take the supplies.

And don't ask questions.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-talkingbarrel-:
It's quiet now. Good.

Take this.

If anyone asks, you heard nothing.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-doorposter-fin:
No notes. Better this way.

Take the supplies.

Let them write at their own homes from now on.
albase:innkeeper-missingmugs-reward-jour:
The mugs no longer ‘disappear’ on their own.

The innkeeper was pleased you didn't make a scene.
albase:innkeeper-talkingbarrel-reward-jo:
The cellar fell silent. The patrons were left without a show.

The innkeeper said that's how it should be.
albase:innkeeper-doorposter-reward-journ:
The notes on the door have stopped appearing.

The innkeeper handed over the supplies and pretended it was just another day.
